title: Power of Attorney and Healthcare Directives

sections.title: Empower Trusted Voices When You Can't Decide
sections.subtitle: Design financial and medical directives that speak for you during incapacity

items: Differences between durable, springing, and limited powers of attorney
Key elements of healthcare proxies and living wills
How to choose and prepare your agents

sections.title: Financial Power of Attorney
sections.content: A durable power of attorney lets a trusted agent manage finances if you're unable. Define the scope clearly—banking, real estate, tax matters—and discuss responsibilities before naming someone.

points.title: Healthcare Proxy
points.description: Appoints a decision maker when you cannot communicate. Share your values and preferences in advance.

points.title: Living Will
points.description: Outlines treatment choices (life support, pain management, organ donation) to guide caregivers.

points.title: HIPAA Authorization
points.description: Allows medical staff to share information with your proxy and family—critical for smooth coordination.

sections.title: Keep Originals Accessible
sections.content: Store signed directives in a fireproof safe and give copies to agents, physicians, and close family members.

sections.title: Directive Prep Checklist
steps: List potential agents and note their availability, geographic location, and communication style.
Define your medical preferences regarding life support, pain relief, and end-of-life care.
Consult your healthcare provider to clarify medical terminology and implications.
Execute documents according to state witness/notary requirements.
Upload secure digital copies to a patient portal or cloud vault for rapid access.

sections.title: Conduct a Family Meeting
sections.content: Walk through your directives with loved ones to avoid confusion and ensure everyone understands their role.
